HC Tang, Financial Enthusiast, Budgeting at The SocietyLevel 8. WizardAnswered on 02 May 2019Normal car is a liability due to the need to feed petrol, maintaining and changing parts to ensure machines working as intended. Not to mention the time need to bring it to repair, servicing. Rare collection could be an exotic investment that may bring returns when you sell it years later but maintenance is even higher while owning the car. Either way we look at it , it's merely a machine that brings us from Point A to Point B. In Singapore context, it is a very bad investment. If you have a lot of extra $, it is fine. GeniusAnswered on 02 May 2019An (appreciating) asset puts money into your pocket.A liability takes money out of your pocket.When you buy and use a car, you need to take money out of your pocket for expenses such as fuel, maintenance, parking fee, etc.Therefore, the car is a liability.0 comments1

Loh Tat TianLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 02 May 2019It really depends on what the term "asset" means to you.In accounting terms, "asset" means anything that has a price that you can sell off to generate cash etc. Income generating is something that produce income (can be dividend, royalty, etc etc)Depreciating means it is losing value over time. Cash itself depreciates through inflation. Car loses its sale value over time. So yes, a car is a depreciating asset. If it is used in business to generate income, it is a income generating depreciating asset.0 comments0
